poem:
**Sauna Club**

The room  
a white box  
of heat.

We sit—  
close as coins  
in a pocket—  
motionless,

no book, no bar,  
no questions allowed.

Only breath  
and the small  
salt talk of skin.

To see each other  
without gin,

to sweat out  
the old loudness

and step  
back into the street  
clear.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Why are saunas suddenly everywhere? I think it’s to do with booze | Zoe Williams Obviously I’m familiar with the concept of the sauna, because I’ve been to Iceland, where most socialising seems to entail either being unbearably cold or way too hot, but never until 2026 have I been required to engage with it at the coal face, which is to say, go to one. I thought that if anyone went, it was because they had a medical condition. This turns out not to be true, and suddenly saunas are huge. One friend has a sauna club. Another friend has opened a sauna. Even though I’m still nowhere near understanding the point, I went along because what else could I do? I’m a joiner. These are the rules: even though you’re sitting really close to people, motionless, with nothing to look at or read or do, nothing standing between you and your own thoughts, you are still not allowed to interrogate others about why they’re there or even the basics – how they know each other, if they’re in love, whether they had a nice day. Related: ‘It lowers inhibition’: how saunas are challenging UK pubs as the place to meet So I couldn’t talk to strangers and just had to observe all this with my own eyes and ears: I think people are pretty serious about wanting to see each other without having to get drunk. It’s been a pretty slow evolution, from a shy flirtation with socialising". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
